_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The following information is provided in the same sequence and format as outlined under the Data Element Instructions for the Executive Summary.

1.0  The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at your facility

The overall approach to chemical safety at the Jupiter WTP is in accordance with the EPA RMP and OSHA PSM requirements.  Senior management commitment to safety has been established as a top-down function that includes employee involvement and associated agencies and appropriate vendors and contractors.  The Town of Jupiter policies include local response to small spills, 911 responses to releases and an on-going maintenance and training efforts that include appropriate documentation.

2.0  Your facility and the regulated substances handled

The Town of Jupiter WTP provides potable drinking water to the residents of the Town of Jupiter, Town of Juno Beach, and in unincorporated areas of Palm Beach County and Martin County.  The Town uses chlorine gas injection for disinfection to make the drinking water potable.  This process has been in use for approximately 36 years.  The process is stable and no releases have occurred over this period.  The WTP produces an average of 15.5 million gallons per day (MGD) of water daily for a service area of 88,000 residents @ 2.43 people per residential connection.  There are 28,000 connections.  The WTP uses and estimated 1,675 lbs. of chlorine daily depending on the season of the year of chlorine with a total storage capacity of 80,000 lbs. or 40 containers.  Other substances are used but are well below the regulated EPA threshold limits.

3.0  The worst case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s)

Here is a summary of the two release scenarios of chlorine:

The worst case release is a one-ton container (2,000 pounds) of gaseous chlorine spewing at a release rate of 110 pounds per minute in a total of 600 seconds.  This release scenario has a potential of a 0.9-mile

radius plume dispersion.  The worst case scenario could negatively impact 8,955 persons, 577 public receptors and 2 environmental receptors (based on Jupiter GIS, 2010 Census).  

The alternative release scenario consists of 317 pounds of chlorine spewing at a release rate of 10.5 lbs/min. over a one-hour period.  The alternate release could have a 0.1-mile radius plume dispersal and could negatively impact 80 persons and 25 public receptors (based on Jupiter GIS, 2010 Census).


4.0   The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps

The details of the Town of Jupiter WTP Prevention Programs are contained in Part VI: Accident Prevention Programs of the written RMP document.  In the document, there are policies and procedures to ensure the continued safe operation of the chlorination process.  They include SOPs, employee awareness and involvement, maintaining the mechanical integrity of the process, procedures for management of change, revising and updating the process hazard analysis (PHA), performing pre-startup reviews and employee training.

5.0  The five year accident history

The Jupiter WTP personnel have conducted a thorough record search and have not discovered any reportable releases in the history of the WTP.  This covers a period much longer than the five-year period.

Occasional small chlorine leaks, associated with packing glands and valve stem packing have periodically occurred.  When these events occur, the contamination is quickly removed by the chlorine scrubber.



6.0  The Emergency Response Program

The Jupiter WTP Emergency Response Program (ERP) and the Emergency Spill Response Program (ESRP) are presented in this RMP.  The Town of Jupiter policies are in effect that allows employee response to small releases.  Large releases are directed to the Palm Beach County Regional Hazardous Materials Response Team (PBCRHMRT) with 911 calls, and evacuation of the facility.

Personnel training

and drills are conducted for WTP personnel.  Alert systems are already in place.

The Fire Department and Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) handle public notification in a larger, more encompassing regional response plan, outside the jurisdiction of the WTP.

 
7.0  Planned changes to improve safety

Changes to improve safety are typically derived from deficient findings found during the 3-year regulatory required compliance audits, during process hazard analysis (PHA) revisions or re-validations, during routine mechanical maintenance and technological changes.

An action item list is generated whenever a compliance audit or a PHA revision or re-validation is performed. The list states the safety action; the responsible party for completing the action; the priority deadline; the reference to the appropriate section in the compliance audit or PHA that dealt with the action; and the current status of the action item.  The PHA Action Item List is provided in Appendix E of the written Risk Management Plan (RMP).  The EPA RMP compliance audits and the corresponding action item list can be found in Appendix C of the RMP.


As a result of the 2014 PHA re-validation, the following safety improvements will be implemented:
1.	If sheltering-in-place becomes necessary (e.g., contaminant wind plume blows toward the Admin and Water Plant Offices thereby making evacuation through the east entrance hazardous or imprudent in a worst case release scenario), personnel from these two buildings will go to the second floor of the Water Plant Offices bldg. The HVAC units to this bldg. will be switched off to prevent the intrusion of contaminated air.
2.	To prevent employees, contractors and visitors from inadvertently entering the plant during a detected chlorine contaminant breach or during an emergency evacuation, an emergency strobe with the appropriate warning signage, will be installed at the main entrance/exit of the facility. 
3.	Signage to reflect the requi
rements of the newly revised OSHA HazCom standard will be posted at the main entrances to the chlorine building.
